awd_titl_txt: Mechanics of Topologically Interlocked Stereotomic Material Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This research investigates the reconciliation of opposed properties in material systems through the use of stereotomic architectures. Engineers and scientists continuously search for high damage tolerant materials and structures. Stereotomy is the art of cutting materials into geometric shapes. The cut blocks are then assembled into complex structures. Scientists have recently discovered new principles for the assembly process. The result is Stereotomic Material Systems with new architectures realized as interlocking assemblies based on single and multiphase tessellations.  This research then aims to reconcile opposed properties such as strength-toughness, brittleness-ductility, and hardness-wave speed. It also aims to find approaches to control such properties. The outcomes will have impact on several technologies, including flexible electronics, battery systems, armor, and high temperature structures. The PI will develop related educational modules in the context of engineering mechanics. These activities will introduce pre-college students to engineering principles. The awardee also will develop new graduate-level educational content on architectured material systems. He will engage undergraduate students in related research experiences.  Advances in the scientific discourse on architectured material systems will be undertaken through an international symposium on the subject. A collaboration with a small business will enable the implementation of the stereotomic material systems.

Stereotomic Material Systems (SMS) are assemblies of polyhedra on underlying tessellation patterns. The present work focuses on non-regular single-phase and multi-phase stereotomic material systems. For static loading, measurements of stiffness, strength and toughness under quasistatic loading are conducted. Under impact loading, experiments to determine wave front speed, unit element velocity and decay rates are planned. There are two main research questions: (1) given the large number of possibilities of tessellations providing potential architectural templates for SMS, and the option to consider multi-material systems, the question is how complexity in the SMS architecture would control SMS stiffness, strength and toughness. (2) since unit-to-unit element contact interactions in SMS are dependent on the degree of transverse deformation, the question is how such contact nonlinearity will manifest itself in the dynamics of the SMS response following impact loading, and how such dynamic response depends on SMS architecture complexity. Multi-material 3D printing is employed to manufacture specimens. Experiments under static and dynamic mechanical load are conducted. Theory and finite element simulation are used in the analysis.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Living systems are mostly not monolithic but rather assembled from individual building blocks. Fish have many individual hard scales, rather than a uniform and monolithic, hard skin. Scale structures is multifunctional: they provide protection but also flexibility such that fish can swim.

The objective of the intellectual merit the award was to advance the engineering mechanics knowledge of systems assembled of individual building blocks.

Here, we study material systems assembled from individual building blocks. We employ principles of material system design and engineering mechanics in our investigation. We focus on topologically interlocked stereotomic material systems. We create load bearing system from building blocks without the use of adhesives. Our investigation employs computer aided design tools to create the building blocks and assemblies. It employs 3D printing for the realization of the respective assemblies. We use non-linear finite element models to simulate the system response in the computer. In addition, we define compact, semianalytical equations to describe the system behavior. We compare our simulation and model data with data from experiments.

We investigated the most fundamental topologically interlocked materials system. This is the dense packing of tetrahedra in a plane. We establish laws relating building block count, block size, and assembly size to the system response. We analyze stiffness, strength, and toughness. The model is based on the concept of an equivalent truss structure to mimic the load paths in the assembly. Our model laws relate well with data from computer simulations.

We investigated the rules underpinning material architecture and properties in periodic system (Figure 1). Our material systems span the available Archimedean and Laves tiling space. We established rules on how to select from available geometries for the most desirable mechanical properties.

For an irregular system, we discovered that building block size variation possesses a significant effect on mechanical behavior (Figure 2). We demonstrate that the regular, period system is by no means the best choice when it comes to stiffness, strength and toughness. We can relate this finding to the role of block-to-block interaction. We define a relevant geometric parameter for this measure.

We also consider impact loading on the topologically interlocked material systems. Using 1D assemblies, we find that these support travelling waves, and that the block and assembly geometry play a significant role in setting the wave propagation speed (Figure 3). Wave propagation patterns in 2D have significant complexity, in particular for out of plane impact. The ability sustain such transverse loads is unique for these systems and is not available in other known acoustic metamaterials.

We establish a class of light weight material assemblies in which we use hollow building blocks. We demonstrate the density - property scaling laws for such systems.

For non-planar system, we consider tube structures assembled from building blocks. Even in the non-planar configuration, the assembled systems can keep the damage tolerance observed for planar configurations (Figure 4). We define what such conditions amount to. We extend our equivalent truss model to the tube configuration. The analysis and experiments are again in good agreement.

We discover that topologically interlocked material systems can exhibit a chiral response. Thereby, an applied axial load leads to a reaction force and a reaction moment. To characterize such a response, we introduce a vector field describing the material architecture. We establish the curl of the material architecture and the sum of the curls as a measure of chirality.

Finally, we demonstrate the opportunities to active control of structures based on topologically interlocked assemblies. We realize such systems by a combination of shape memory wires with the assembly. We can thereby control the system response to optimize energy dissipation under a constraint of maximum force. Such behavior is desirable for adaptive packaging systems. We extend the equivalent truss model to this application which allows us to provide efficient simulations of the externally controlled physical system.

The broader impact objectives enabled training opportunities for several undergraduate and graduate students (Figure 5). A cohort of undergraduate students conducted summer research on assembled toy systems such as Legos (TM), stickbombs, puzzle spheres, on 3D printed and machined building block systems, on theory and on computer modeling. Several undergraduate students are from under-represented groups in STEM. The project provided continued opportunities for undergraduate students during COVID closures. Graduate students worked on three MS and two PhD theses. The REU supplement allowed for one student to be recruited to graduate school. One undergraduate researcher went on to receive a NSF GRF award. Knowledge created in this course is now part of the syllabus of a graduate course. This course is delivered online to students across the globe. In collaboration with industry partners, we applied knowledge gained in this award to an engineering component currently in use in many highway trucks and to the design of novel approaches to EV battery packs.


Last Modified: 09/22/2022
Modified by: Thomas H Siegmund

Images (1 of )
  • The Stereotomic Material System is created by the assembly of disphenoids (tetrahedra in which opposite edges have equal lengths).
    Thomas Siegmund, Purdue University
    Creative Commons
    Thomas H Siegmund
    Figure 1: A Stereotomic Material System
  • Tube structures are constructed as Stereotomic Material Systems. Both interlocking and non-interlocking configurations are considered. For the non-interlocking system, block push-out dominates, but in interlocked systems, the deformation spreads through the tube.
    Thomas Siegmund, Purdue University
    Creative Commons
    Thomas H Siegmund
    Figure 4: Tubes from Stereotomic Material Systems
  • Undergraduate students investigated a series of examples of material systems created from the principle of stereotomic assembly. The examples shown are a spine-type assembly with elastic connectors, large LEGO(TM) beams assembled from many individual bricks, popsickle stick bombs, and the CAD design
    Thomas Siegmund, Purdue University
    Creative Commons
    Thomas H Siegmund
    Figure 5: Examples of undergraduate research projects related to stereotomic material systems.
  • Irregular Stereotomic Material Systems can be both stiffer, stronger and tougher than regular systems. The rules derived from analyzing irregularity allow for the design of the stiffest, strongest and toughest Stereotomic Material Systems.
    Thomas Siegmund, Purdue University
    Creative Commons
    Thomas H Siegmund
    Figure 2: Irregular Stereotomic Material Systems
  • A Stereotomic Material System is created as a row of tetrahedra and the wave propagation along the row is computed. A zig-zag wave path emerges as the result of the stereotomic construction princple.
    Thomas Siegmund, Purdue University
    Creative Commons
    Thomas H Siegmund
    Figure 3: Wave propagation in a Stereotomic Material System
